Name: Record (ISO 15489-1:2016)
Question: Record (ISO 15489-1:2016 definition)
Answer: Information created or received and maintained as evidence and as an asset by an organization or person, in pursuit of legal obligation or in the transaction of business.

Name: Original Order (Society American Archivists)
Question: Original Order (Society American Archivists definition)
Answer: The organization and sequence of records established by the creator of the records. FR: l'ordre primitif, respect de l'ordre intérieur.

Name: Respect des Fonds
Question: Respect des Fonds
Answer: ...or respect pour des fonds. Translated literally as respect of background (context). A principle for grouping records by the entirety of their context, by administration, organization, individual, entity, etc.

Name: Provenance
Question: Provenance
Answer: The background of a record that reveals its context, but which also allows the demonstration of the authenticity and integrity of the record’s content and meaning.

Name: Integrity (UNESCO, 2003)
Question: Integrity (UNESCO, 2003, definition)
Answer: The state of being whole, uncorrupted and free of unauthorised and undocumented changes.

Name: Authenticity (UNESCO, 2003)
Question: Authenticity (UNESCO, 2003, definition)
Answer: Quality of genuineness and trustworthiness of some digital materials, as being what they purport to be, either as an original object or as a reliable copy derived by fully documented processes from an original.

Name: Archival Silences
Question: Archival Silences
Answer: Voices, and memories, of individuals, groups, or communities, and their activities – their marginalization, that don’t appear in the archival/documentary record due to the biases, unwittingly or otherwise, of the collecting institution; the nature of custodial archives; and/or an inability to access, and make available, the content of the record in meaningful ways.

Name: File (Digital)
Question: File (Digital)
Answer: An information encoding that can be retrieved from digital storage and interpreted by a computer to be presented to the user in a suitable way.

Name: File (Archival) (Society of American Archivists)
Question: File (Archival) (Society of American Archivists, definition)
Answer: A group of documents related by use or topic, typically housed in a folder (or a group of folders for a large file). The plural, files, is the whole of a collection of records.

Name: Folder (Archival) (Society of American Archivists)
Question: Folder (Archival) (Society of American Archivists, definition)
Answer: A sheet of cardboard or heavy paper stock that is used as a loose cover to keep documents and other flat materials together, especially for the purposes of filing.

Name: Folder (Digital)
Question: Folder (Digital)
Answer: A delineation of digital storage that organizes files into groups. Synonymous with the term directory. A directory inside another is often called a sub-directory.

Name: Redaction
Question: Redaction
Answer: The obfuscation of sensitive, or secretive information in a document, e.g. to provide access e.g. to satisfy a freedom of information request. The information redacted may be protected through various legislation, e.g. data protection acts. Redaction protects individuals and organisations in appropriate circumstances.

Name: Record Group
Question: Record Group
Answer: A record group is a collection of records, organized by transferring, or depositing agency, sometimes divided into organizational division.

Name: Series System
Question: Series System
Answer:
• A collection of records organized by function, replacing the record group where the same function may be managed by different agencies over time.
  • The series model was developed in Australia by Peter Scott in the 1960s.
  • The system emphasises multiple and dynamic context for records and enables those contexts to be assigned to archival records.
  • Contextual entities described by Cunningham (2012), include individuals, families, organisations, project teams, government agencies and portfolios, governments themselves, functions and activities.

Name: Series
Question: Series
Answer: A functional grouping of records.

Name: Sub-series
Question: Sub-series
Answer: A further grouping of records underneath a series, for example, by type, form, or content.

Name: Appraisal
Question: Appraisal
Answer: Appraisal is the analysis of an organisation’s business context, business activities and risks. This will determine what information and records need to be created, what are of high risk/high value, and how long they need to be managed to meet business and community needs and expectations.

Name: Retention and Disposal
Question: Retention and Disposal
Answer: Organizational awareness of the types of record being maintained and how long they need to be kept to meet business needs, legal requirements, and in the case of government, the obligation to open and transparent government.

Name: Disposal
Question: Disposal
Answer: A means of controlling records at an organization through: retention, destruction, transfer, and in some cases, the sale of records to another organization, providing there is authorization to do so. An example disposal action may be transfer from a government agency to a government archive.

Name: Disposal Authority
Question: Disposal Authority
Answer: Description of appraised classes of records and the disposal action that is supposed to be applied to them and after what time. A disposal authority is signed by a suitable jurisdictional authority.

Name: Sentencing
Question: Sentencing
Answer: The application of disposal actions to a group of records in accordance with a suitable disposal authority.

Name: Information Asset (The National Archives, UK)
Question: Information Asset (The National Archives, UK)
Answer: An information asset is a body of information, defined and managed as a single unit so it can be understood, shared, protected and exploited efficiently. Information assets have recognisable and manageable value.

Name: Information Asset Register
Question: Information Asset Register
Answer: A register of information assets that describes what they are, their value, their life-cycle, and risk profile.

Name: Agency
Question: Agency
Answer: A governmental department that transfers records to a national/government archive.

Name: Donor
Question: Donor
Answer: An individual or organisation that donates records to an archival institution or library.

Name: File Classification Scheme
Question: File Classification Scheme
Answer: or Business Classification Scheme, is the folder and directory layout adopted in a business, organized by function, client, activity etc. Such that records are contextualized, described appropriately, and retrievable.

Name: Collection Policy
Question: Collection Policy
Answer: A statement that describes the collecting principles of the archival institution which may include: legal obligations to collect; jurisdiction; geographical areas; chronological period; media-type; and collection methodology, plus other logical grouping of content relevant to the policy.

Name: Fixity
Question: Fixity
Answer: Fixity is the property of remaining fixed. That is, the features of a record that we can use to determine that a record has not been changed. Context, date ranges, materials used, and in the case of digital records, checksums enable us to demonstrate a record has not been modified. Fixity is key in demonstrating authenticity and integrity.

Name: Information and Records Management
Question: Information and Records Management
Answer: The management of information in an organization throughout its contexts.

Name: Continuum Model
Question: Continuum Model
Answer:
The recognition that records are multi-dimensional and develop and gain new context and value across a continuous period of time (a continuum) across a number of organizations and activities as they are moved about and are reused.

Records do not simply have a beginning and end of life with deprecating value as may be in a life-cycle approach to records and information management.

Name: Intrinsic Value
Question: Intrinsic Value
Answer:
Value intrinsic to a record that cannot alone be captured through copying or transcription.

According to the Society of American Archivists the value intrinsic to the record may come from: form, layout, materials, or process. It may also be based on an item's direct relationship to a significant person, activity, event, organization, or place.

Name: Create Maintain
Question: Create Maintain
Answer: The principle in records and information management that asks that records are created with a long-term view to their maintenance with consideration given to the record keeping obligations of the organization. Organizations will consider application of disposal classes at point of creation, as well as considering other legislative requirements, obligations to transparency and stakeholders, amongst other dimensions of the records and information management continuum.

Name: Physical Carrier
Question: Physical Carrier
Answer: The medium on which digital records have been transferred to an organization.

Name: Participatory Archives
Question: Participatory Archives
Answer: An archive or collection that seeks active engagement from the community, causes, organisations, and activities that it represents. Custodial control and maintenance of the archive may support the development of archival skills within that community to develop and maintain the collection further. A post-custodial view would see the control of the archive passed from the archival professionals to the community.

Name: Cardigan
Question: Cardigan
Answer: Knitwear. A preferred sartorial choice made by the discerning archivist.
